title: Improved STEM Imaging Using Deep Learning Based Compressed Sensing
content: Scanning Transmission Electron Microscopy (STEM) is a well-established method for looking into the physical properties of complex nanostructures. However, a major drawback is that acquiring very high-resolution images leads to negative effects such as radiolysis and knock-on damage [1]. It has been shown that damage is reduced by sub-sampling the beam positions and decreasing dwell time, speeding up data acquisition at the cost of an increased signal-to-noise ratio [2].
